Directions
For the Batter:
In a blender, blend eggs, milk, flour, sugar, and salt until smooth, about 20 seconds. Cover and refrigerate for at least 30 minutes or up to 8 hours.
Serious Eats/ Morgan Hunt Glaze
Adjust oven rack to middle position. Set a 12-inch cast-iron skillet on the rack, and preheat oven to 450°F (230°C). Remove batter from refrigerator while oven preheats.
Serious Eats/ Morgan Hunt Glaze
When oven has preheated, remove skillet from oven, and add butter; using gloved hands or oven mitts, carefully swirl skillet to coat bottom and edges of pan with butter until completely melted, about 20 seconds. Pour batter into pan and bake for 10 minutes. With skillet still in oven, reduce oven temperature to 400°F (205°C) and bake until golden brown and significantly puffed around edges, 8 to 10 minutes more.
Serious Eats/ Morgan Hunt Glaze
Meanwhile, for the Whipped Crème Fraîche:
In a medium bowl, whisk crème fraîche, sugar, vanilla paste, and salt until medium-stiff peaks form, about 1 minute. Cover with a plate or plastic wrap, and refrigerate until ready to use. If mixture has loosened, briefly whisk again to medium-stiff peaks before serving.
Serious Eats/ Morgan Hunt Glaze
To Serve:
Remove Dutch baby from oven. Using a small fine-mesh sieve, dust pancake with confectioners' sugar, and serve with whipped crème fraîche, lemon wedges, and fresh berries, if desired. Serve immediately.
Serious Eats/ Morgan Hunt Glaze
Equipment
Blender, 12-inch cast iron skillet, small fine-mesh sieve
Notes
Vanilla extract can be substituted for the paste in equal amounts, but its flavor won’t be quite as robust.
Make-Ahead and Storage
The Dutch baby is best eaten immediately after it's baked.
